name: Saver's Credit
description:
The Saver's Credit incentives retirement contributions like IRAs, 401(k) and Roth-IRAs for filers with adjusted gross income (AGI) up to:

MFJ: $66,000
HoH: $49,500
All Others: $33,000

for Tax Year 2020.
condition: Age, dependence, filing state, and AGI determine the rate (0 - 50%) of your retirement contributions you can take as a nonrefundable credit

name: Foreign Income Exclusion
description:
For expats living abroad, if you pass the residency or physical test (nominally 95% of your time abroad) you can exclude as much as:
* $107,600 of your income if single
* $215,200 if MFJ and both are abroad.

You cannot exclude more than your income.
condition: Live abroad and pass physical or residency tests

name: Foreign Tax Credit
description: If you invest in foreign assets and are taxed by a foreign entity, you can choose to deduct those taxes as a credit or a deduction.
condition: Have taxes issues by a foreign country or US possession.

name: Charitable Donations (Itemized)
description:
For Tax Years 2022-2025, 60 percent of your AGI is the most you can donate in cash. This is the reversion to pre-COVID rules as in years 2021-2021 you could donate up to 100 percent of your AGI. In 2026+ the limit will be 50 percent of your AGI. The donations you made are deductible on Schedule A.

If you do give cash or checks, any single amount over $250 needs documentation, and if you gave goods, you also need documentation > $250, but if over $500, you need form 8283.
condition: Itemized deduction, Donations, and use of Form 8283

name: Student Loan Interest
description:
Student loan interest is deductible up to $2,500 per tax return. The amount, if above $600, should be reported to you on a 1098-E form.

This is an 'Above the line' deduction that is based on your Modified AGI (MAGI) and it does have an income limit ($85k single / $170k MFJ).

But the IRS allows someone else (like your parents) to make the student loan payments and will treat that as them paying you and you paid the loan.

That works well for students not claimed as a dependent due to age because it will be the student's tax return that gets the deduction and likely has a lower MAGI than the student's parents.
condition: Pay student loan debt incurring interest charges and be below MAGI limits

name: American Opportunity Tax Credit
description:
The American Opportunity Tax Credit (AOTC) is a credit for qualified education expenses paid for an eligible student for the first four years of higher education. Your maximum annual credit per student is $2,500.

This credit also has a refundable component in that if your credit brings your tax owed to zero, you can get another 40% of any remaining amount of the credit, up to $1,000 refunded to you.

This credit is generally for parents paying for their chidren's college education, where you would receive a 1098-T from the college.

But there are income limits based on your filing status that can reduce the $2500 credit to zero.
condition: Receive 1098-T for your dependent and be within MAGI limits

name: Advance Child Tax Credit
description:
Advanced payments should have been sent to you if you qualify. You would qualify if you filed 2019 or 2020 tax returns and claimed the Child Tax Credit, the IRS gave you Economic Impact Payments (EIPs) for non-filers, or have a qualifying child under 18 at the end of 2021.

Since the IRS is not guaranteeing accuracy and you feel you are due this credit, see the Source link for the IRS's Advance Child Tax Credit Eligibility Assisstant.
condition: Meet income requirements, file 2019 or 2020 tax return and take Child Tax Credit.

name: Earned Income Tax Credit
description:
The Earned Income Tax Credit (EIC) is a credit for low and moderate income workers. The EITC can lower your taxes owed, and could lead to a refund! The amount of credit is based on your income, amount of children and not having much in investment income (less than $3,650).

There are some special qualifying rules if you are in the military, clergy, or have dependents with disabilities.

You also cannot claim this if filing as Married filing Separately.
condition: Have low to moderate income, and not be filing MFS

name: Recovery Rebate Credit(2020)
description:
Recovery Rebate payments #1 and #2 were sent to taxpayers as  advanced payments. Those 2 payments, if received, do not have to be put on your next tax filing. If you were supposed to get those payments, and you didn't or got less than you should, you needed to file your 2020 tax return to get them.

Eligibility was based on income (AGI) maximums of $160k (MFJ/QW), $120k (HoH), or $80k (any other filing status).

To get the credit on your 2020 Tax Return you had to be eligible to receive payments #1 and #2 but didn't, or the payment #1 was below $1,200 (single), $2,400 (MFJ) + $500 per qualifying child.  Similarly if payment #2 was below $500 (single), $1,200 (MFJ) + $600 per qualifying child. The credit you would get is the difference in what you should have gotten less what you did get.
condition: Have low to moderate income, and not be filing MFS

name: Credit for the Elderly or Disabled
description:
This credit is for either the Elderly (per the IRS, Age 65 by the last day of the year) or if younger than 65, retired with permanent disability or receiving tax disability income or simply, by Jan 1, you had not reached mandatory retirement age.

For purposes of determining the credit amount, your AGI must be more than $17,500 (single), $20,000 (MFJ, one spouse eligible), $25,000 (MFJ both spouses eligible) or $12,500 (MFS).

Initially you get at most, $5,000. That is reduced by excess AGI. nontaxable social security, and 15% of the remaining is used to help determine your credit.
condition: Have low income, and be retired with a disaility or 65 or older.

name: Reinvesting Dividends
description:
While not a true deduction, this matters if you sell investments and pay Capital Gains. This is because you pay gains based on the sale price less the 'basis' of the asset. The basis starts as the purchase price you paid.

But if that asset produces dividends and you elect to have those reinvested in buying more shares, you basis is increased thereby lowering your Capital Gains.
taxline: Part I or Part II (e) Cost (or other basis)
condition: Reinvest dividends in any brokerage or taxable account

name: IRA Deduction
description:
Contributions to an Individual Retirement Account (IRA) are deductible up to $6,000 ($12k if MFJ) subject to MAGI income limits (Single $124k; MFJ $196k.

But even if you income exceeds those numbers, your IRA contributions may be elgible to be 'backdoored' to a ROTH IRA (which if above ROTH contribution income, you'll only pay 6% of that)
condition: Fund an IRA by April 15th AFTER tax year

name: HSA Deduction
description: Contributions to a Health Savings Account (HSA) is a great way to lower taxes. There is no income restriction and most employers offer a high-deductible, low monthly premium insurance plan that couples with an HSA. You'll receive form 8889 which will help you calculate the deduction.
condition: Contribute to HSA and receive form 8889

name: K-12 Teacher(s) Deduction
description:
You can deduct $250 ($500 if filing jointly and both are educators). This is for non-reimbursed expenses for materials such as books, supplies, courses, computer equipment and software. Also, any COVID related supplies like disinfectants bought after March 12, 2020. 

You claim this deduction on Schedule 1, line 10. There are some limits that won’t make sense to many people, but also fall into corner cases.
condition: you and/or your spouse are teachers in K-12th Grade

name: Moving Expenses for our brave Military
description: Permanent moves ordered by the military and paid for by the military avoid taxation on that reimbursement. Normally, an employer reimbursing you triggers a tax on that money, but if you are (and we thank you) an active duty military member, you don't have to pay these taxes.
condition: You are an active duty military member and are required to move and are reimbursed for it.

name: Self-Employed SEP, SIMPLE plans
description: Self-Employed retirement plans such as SEP, SIMPLE and other qualified plans, if funded during the tax year or to the filing date of the business, can be deducted on each partner/member or self-employed individual's tax return.
condition: Fill out form SE; open a SEP for employees and fund them.

name: Self-Employed health insurance
description: If a small business has a net profit, costs for health insurance premiums may be deducted by the partner/member or self-employed indidividual.
condition: Fill out form SE

name: Self-Employed taxes
description: After computing self-employment taxes on form SE, one-half of those taxes can be deducted.  SE Taxes are for Social Security and Medicare payments, much like an employer would withhold from an employees paycheck. Because Self-Employed people using pass-thru entities don't always give themselves a bi-weekly paycheck, the IRS asks for SE taxes but you get 1/2 of that as an above the line deduction.
condition: Fill out form SE

name: Home Sale Capital Gains Exclusion
description: Selling your home can be an emotional event. Home is where the heart is! But the US Government gives you a little bonus here, and allows a portion of your gain on the sale of your home be exluded from income tax in what is called a Section 121 exclusion.
condition: Sell your home and compute the gain after sales expenses as sale price less adjusted basis

name: Medical Expenses
description: Medical expenses, including dental, are itemized and are 'below the line' meaning they are limited by your AGI (adjusted gross income). That makes it important to have 'above the line' deductions which lower your AGI.  For 2020, Medical and Dental expenses in excess of 7.5% of your AGI are deductible.  And you can deduct medical and dental expenses for youself, your spoouse, and your dependents
condition: Have receipts,

name: Impairment Related Expenses
description:
Impairment-related expenses are those associated to an impairment you or your spouse or dependent has that requires treatment to keep or seek employment. This are similar to regular medical expenses; however, you don't have a 7.5% AGI floor to exceed.

In fact, you can include a home office you legitimately use in this section as well as modification costs to vehicles and homes.
condition: Have receipts,

name: Mortgage Interest & Points
description:
You can deduct the mortgage interest and points paid on a primary and secondary home as 'below the line' deductions.

Most of this information is furnished to you on a Form 1098. You are limited to mortgage principal amounts of $750k though.
condition: Form 1098

name: Mortgage Insurance Premiums
description: You can deduct mortgage insurance premiums as 'below the line' deductions. Most of this information is furnished to you on a Form 1098.  You are limited to mortgage principal amounts of $750k though.
condition: Form 1098

name: Property Taxes
description: You can deduct property taxes levied from an assessed value of your home.
condition: Taxes are based on assessed value

name: Casualty and Theft Losses
description: Physical (not reputational) damage, to your property may entitle you to a deduction. Theft and losses to personal property must subtract $100 from the net of loss vs insurance repaid, and then has to exceed 10% of your AGI
condition: Federal Disaster

name: State and Local Taxes
description:
State taxes that an employer withholds from your W-2s can be deducted but only up to a maximum of $10,000 combined with real estate and personal property taxes due to the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that imposed a 'SALT' limit of $10k.

Also, and this benefits taxpayers in the 7 states without state income tax: sales tax paid may be substituted instead of State and Local.

name: Hire your Children
description: As young as age 7, your dependents can work for your small business.  If both of the dependents parents are the only partners in a partnership (which includes 2 member LLCs taxed as a partnership), then the dependent doesn't pay Self-Employed taxes unless the are 18. Works to save money for college, a car for them, etc. while lowering the partnership net income.
condition: Pay them a reasonable salary for their age & responsibilies to the business

name: Qualified solar electric property costs
description: Qualified solar electric property costs are deductible up to 26% of the cost to you. However, as this is a nonrefundable credit, it cannot reduce your tax burden into a refund. You must use the Residential Energy Efficient Property Credit worksheet to balance your tax liability vs other nonrefundable credits there.  Only solar panels and solar roofing and tiles can be used, not structural support.

name: Nonbusiness Energy Property Credit
description: 10% of the amount paid or incurred for qualified energy efficiency improvements installed during 2020, and any residential energy property costs paid of incurred in 2020.
condition: Lifetime $500 credit

name: Child & Dependent Care Tax Credit
description:
This is a credit specifically for working families that pay for the costs associated with providing care for their children or disabled dependents.

To make the claim your dependent has to be age 12 or less by the final day of the tax year, and you had to pay someone (other than a dependent of yours) or organization to care for them, such as a daycare facility.

Your income will determine what percentage (20% to 35% for 2020) you can apply against costs.
condition: You must have earned income and have paid for dependent care so you can work.

name: Qualified solar water heating property costs
description: Qualified solar electric property costs are deductible up to 26% of the cost to you. However, as this is a nonrefundable credit, it cannot reduce your tax burden into a refund. You must use the Residential Energy Efficient Property Credit worksheet to balance your tax liability vs other nonrefundable credits there.

name: Qualified small wind energy property costs
description: Qualified small wind costs are deductible up to 26% of the cost to you. However, as this is a nonrefundable credit, it cannot reduce your tax burden into a refund. You must use the Residential Energy Efficient Property Credit worksheet to balance your tax liability vs other nonrefundable credits there.

name: Qualified geothermal heat pump property costs
description: Qualified geothermal heat pump costs are deductible up to 26% of the cost to you. However, as this is a nonrefundable credit, it cannot reduce your tax burden into a refund. You must use the Residential Energy Efficient Property Credit worksheet to balance your tax liability vs other nonrefundable credits there.

name: Qualified fuel cell Property
description: Qualified fuel cell costs are deductible up to 26% of the cost to you. However, as this is a nonrefundable credit, it cannot reduce your tax burden into a refund. You must use the Residential Energy Efficient Property Credit worksheet to balance your tax liability vs other nonrefundable credits there.

name: Income tax overview
description:
Income tax in the USA is about taxing how much you earn. It starts with all the income reported to the IRS from employers, brokerages, Social Security, banks, quarterly business filings and more. That is your total income.

The IRS excuses a portion of that to arrive at an AGI, short for Adjusted Gross Income. If you've heard of 'the line' that is also the AGI as it used to be the last line on the 1040 front page and the first line on the 1040 second page.

What the IRS excuses from your total income is referred to as 'Above the Line' deductions.

After AGI, the IRS allows another portion of your income to be excused and this is your 'Below the line' deductions before arriving at Taxable Income. That amount is, as you may have figured out, taxed according to tax tables and perhaps Capital Gains rates, to arrive at your Tax which is then compared against what an employer might have withheld to determine what you owe.

From there we get into credits which take what you owe and can reduce it to zero thru 'Nonrefundable credits' or even in some cases 'Refundable credits' and put money in your pocket as a refund (or even increase a refund).

name: Above the line Deductions
description:
Above the line deductions reduce your total income and create the AGI, or Adjusted Gross Income.  They are 'above the line' because your AGI is 'the line' as it used to be the last line on the 1040 first page. Above the line deductions aren't limited by AGI (deductions that are limited by AGI are referred to as 'below the line deductions') and provide very specific relief from taxation.

Teachers in K-12, Small Business Owners, HSA owners, and Retirment investors all are favored to not have some of their income looked at for taxation.   You find all 'above the line' deductions on Schedule One, Part II - Adjustments to Income.

name: Below the line Deductions
description:
Below the line deductions reduce your taxable income, but are limited by your AGI, or Adjusted Gross Income. They are 'below the line' because your AGI is the line as it used to be the last line on the 1040 first page.

Below the line deductions provide direct relief from taxation because they are subtracted from your AGI to produce taxable income.

Taxpayers can choose the Stanard Deduction or if they can itemized above that, Itemized Deductions (Schedule A).

name: Nonrefundable credits
description:
Nonrefundable credits for negating the amount of cash owed to the IRS. They cannot give you a refund, but since these attack the Tax owed, they can reduce it to zero, then applied refundable credits are money back in your wallet.

On the form 1040, after Tax is computed on line 16, 3 lines later at line 19 is the Child tax credit or credit for other dependents, a nonrefundable credit.

Then on line 20 is the rest of the nonrefundable credits from Schedule 3, Part I.

name: Refundable Credits
description:
Refundable Credits are dollar for dollar money coming back to you for a refund or negating the same amount of cash owed. Many feel these are the most important category of deduction or credit due to the 1:1 nature of cash.

You can find most of these on Schedule 3, Part II and some potentially bigger ones appear on Form 1040, lines 27-30.

name: Qualified Business Income (QBI)
description: Many owners of sole proprietorships, partnerships, S corporations and some trusts and estates may be eligible for a qualified business income (QBI) deduction – also called Section 199A – for tax years beginning after December 31, 2017. If you business is a product or otherwise not dependent on your reputation (e.g., lawyer, accountant, etc.) you can get this 20% of net income deduction.
